nodes.text: Machine learning classifiers applied to CT images can detect early-stage lung cancer and SVM will achieve superior accuracy compared to KNN and Random Forest
Dataset: 500 CT images drawn from LIDC-IDRI plus small validation samples from AHRC and AIMS were used, with 70% for training and 30% for testing

Preprocessing: images resized from 512x512x3 to 256x, normalized and denoised using CLAHE, Wiener, Adaptive Gaussian, Gaussian and Gabor filtering; segmentation used thresholding and marker-controlled watershed

Model training: implemented in MATLAB with multi-stage image-processing pipeline and trained classifiers KNN, SVM, and Random Forest using extracted features; KNN uses Euclidean distance, SVM builds max-margin hyperplane, Random Forest ensembles decision trees
Evaluation: 5-fold cross-validation used; performance metrics computed per class include accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, TPR, FPR, AUC, FAR and FRR
Result SVM: average accuracy 95.06%, average precision 0.95, average recall 0.99, average F1-score 0.98, average TPR 0.99 and average FPR 0.26 across folds; ROC-AUC > 0.99 per class
Result KNN and Random Forest: KNN average accuracy 86.89%, precision 0.84, recall 0.98, F1 0.91; Random Forest average accuracy 81.96%, precision 0.78, recall 0.98, F1 0.87
Comparison: SVM outperforms KNN and Random Forest on this dataset likely due to handling complex, high-dimensional decision boundaries better
External validation: small sample sets from AHRC and AIMS were used with radiologist supervision to confirm results from the primary dataset

Conclusion: The proposed image-processing and classification pipeline successfully detects lung cancer from CT images with SVM achieving highest accuracy (95.05%), suggesting potential for aiding early diagnosis
Claim about generalizability: Results suggest the approach could improve early detection and patient outcomes but require testing on larger, more diverse datasets
Limitation: Study used a relatively small sample of 500 images and limited external validation samples, so performance estimates may not generalize across populations and imaging conditions
Future work: expand and diversify data collection across demographics and cancer stages to improve model performance and reliability
